meanings.sent1: She would often imprecate misfortune upon her enemies.
meanings.sent2: The witch imprecated a curse on the village.
meanings.sent3: During the play, the villain would imprecate curses in every scene.
meanings.sent4: The storm seemed to imprecate destruction upon the small town.
meanings.sent5: The old legend tells of a sorcerer who could imprecate doom with a single word.

meanings.definition: To pray for evil to befall.
meanings.sent1: He would secretly imprecate harm on those who wronged him.
meanings.sent2: The villagers would often imprecate against their enemies.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous child would imprecate for his teacher to disappear.
meanings.sent4: The dark clouds seemed to imprecate a storm upon the land.
meanings.sent5: The ancient curse was said to imprecate eternal suffering on those who dared to enter the forbidden temple.
